EDITORIALS

A

THE BRIGHT SPOT
no doubt, by the feeble yells of at least twenty
ENCOURAGED,
rooters, the Jay basketball five lost a listless game to University
of Maryland last Wednesday night to virtually close the present season. After one more game with a similar result to be expected, those
individuals who are interested in athletics at Homewood may look forward to lacrosse—the one bright spot on the intercollegiate sports program at Hopkins. The basketball team did well with the material on
hand, but so did the football team. Even the most ardent friends of
Jays' teams are glad to see the "alibi seasons" end.
Whether or not the student body is really vitally interested in intercollegiate sports, whether vicarious satisfaction is greater than that of
indulging in intra-mural sports can better be discussed after the lacrosse season. No one is interested in teams that habitually lose, but
even when only one team has a successful season, a different light is
thrown on the question.
That the lacrosse team will have a successful season is practically
certain. By a successful season, we do not necessarily mean an undefeated year, but a season during which every contest will be willplayed and a majority of the games won. The most discouraging thing
to the supporter of a team is not to see a close game lost, but to see his
team so outclassed that the opposition sends in the second and third
teams before the close of the contest. Nothing like this will happen
this spring. Hopkins has the hardest schedule ever attemtped, but one
can rest assured that the team will be of the calibre of those twelves
which have given Hopkins the representation it now holds in the lacrosse world.
Only three positions are left open by graduation, and no one of the
veterans is assured of his position due to wealth of material. Maryland,
the only college team that defeated Hopkins last year, loses the majority of its team while all other oponents lose as many veterans if not
more. If one adds to this fact that the coaching staff at Homewood
is as efficient if not more so than any other group in the country, we
can see no reason why this year's twelve should not be one of the most
powerful in the history of the institution.

He remembered in a manner polite

American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its 24 associated telephone companies.
The Bell System is operated by these 24
associated companies, each attuned to the
area it serves. Each enjoys the services of the
staff of the American Company, which is

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 27, 1931

HULLABALOO WORK IS 15 Veteran Stickmen
Available This Year
PROCRESSING SWIFTLY
Photographer On Campus For
Last Time To Take Photographs For Year Book
With the photographer on campus, work on the Hullabaloo is progressing swiftly. Throughout this
week, the sundry group, activity
and fraternity photographs have
been taken. As this is the last time
the photographer will be on campus, it is advised that all seniors
who have not yet done so have their
individual, photographs taken. Appointments may be mad through
P. 0. box 655 or at the Hullabaloo
office in Levering Hall every day.
Sponsors Are Chosen

Sponsors for the eight eminent
social activities of the collegiate
year have all been selected and their
individual portraits are being taken
during the photographer's visit, according to a report emanating from
the Hullabaloo office. The eight
promenades which have the distinction of a sponsor are: First Cotillion, Barnstormers, Second Cotillion, Musical Club. Interfraternity
Ball, Final Cotillion, Night Club
Party and Senior Ball. The last
last three functions are part of the
June Week program.

Only 14 of a class of 325 freshmen in the undergraduate departments of the Johns Hopkins University were forced to discontinue
their studies at Homewood because
of the official regulation requiring
the dropping of students who have
failed in more than three courses.
"That's an unusually small percentage," declared Dr. E. W. Berry,
dean, yesterday. "I'm very much
Pleased with this year's freshman
class."
Twelve
sophomores
were
dropped, it was also announced.
Four undergraduates who were second-year men, but who were given
only first-year rating because of insufficient credits, also failed out. No
juniors or seniors were dropped.
"This is partly due to strictness
in entrance regulations and to postponed fraternity rushing," said the
Hopkins dean.

"An Engineer's 'Hobby'" was
the subject of an address delivered
before the Engineers' Club at 6
West Fayette Street by Mr. Malcolm W. Hill, Hopkins alumnus,
Wednesday afternoon. The speaker,
an active consulting engineer, has
been a member of this Club for
more than twenty-five years. His
talk about an engineer's "hobby"
and his viewpoint on Oriental Rugs
as an investment in pleasure and
profit was appreciatively received
by the audience.

Blue basketball team will close this
season's campaign with the St.

their last encounter, both teams displayed a brand of ball that has always been present in Jay-Johnnie
battles. The game was chock full
of speed with neither team displaying any outstanding advantage
over the other.

be stopped. They grabbed the lead
in the early part of the tussle and
retained it throughout. Ronkin,
Chalmers and Berger gave another
brilliant exhibition of team play

Jack Taylor Shows Up Well

For the Jays, Jack Taylor shoed
up best. He fought hard and with
a little more assistance from his
teammates, would have played a
much better game. Both Kelly
brothers seemed off form while Silverman had the misfortune of being removed by the pers9nal foul
route.
From the opening minutes of
play it was apparent that Maryland
would have little difficulty in defeating Hopkins. Ronkin began to
display speed that dazzled the Jays.
He repeatedly looped shots from
all angles under the basket. Consequently, at the end of the half,
the Old Liners were leading 20-11.
Md. Clik at High Speed

The early minutes of the second
half found Maryland still clicking
at high speed. With but eight minutes to play they had piled up an
overwhelming 31-14 lead. At this
point Coach Shipley, of Maryland,
removed the whole varsity team.
The final score—Maryland, 31;
Hopkins, 22.
This is the third year in succession that the Terrapins have conquered the Jays.
'Disastrous Season' for Jays

From the standpoint of victories,
the Black and Blue basketball team
has had a most disastrous season.
Thus far they have won but four
games out of fifteen. Besides losing both jousts to Maryland, they
also were conquered twice by another rival, Loyola. However, one
could hardly have expected any
better. With no regulars from last
year's team to start with, Coach
Darley was confronted with the
task of constructing an entirely
new team.
Fortunately several of the new
players had had high school experience, but good team work can not

THE BRIGHT SPOT
no doubt, by the feeble yells of at least twenty
ENCOURAGED,
rooters, the Jay basketball five lost a listless game to University
of Maryland last Wednesday night to virtually close the present season. After one more game with a similar result to be expected, those
individuals who are interested in athletics at Homewood may look forward to lacrosse—the one bright spot on the intercollegiate sports program at Hopkins. The basketball team did well with the material on
hand, but so did the football team. Even the most ardent friends of
Jays' teams are glad to see the "alibi seasons" end.
Whether or not the student body is really vitally interested in intercollegiate sports, whether vicarious satisfaction is greater than that of
indulging in intra-mural sports can better be discussed after the lacrosse season. No one is interested in teams that habitually lose, but
even when only one team has a successful season, a different light is
thrown on the question.
That the lacrosse team will have a successful season is practically
certain. By a successful season, we do not necessarily mean an undefeated year, but a season during which every contest will be willplayed and a majority of the games won. The most discouraging thing
to the supporter of a team is not to see a close game lost, but to see his
team so outclassed that the opposition sends in the second and third
teams before the close of the contest. Nothing like this will happen
this spring. Hopkins has the hardest schedule ever attemtped, but one
can rest assured that the team will be of the calibre of those twelves
which have given Hopkins the representation it now holds in the lacrosse world.
Only three positions are left open by graduation, and no one of the
veterans is assured of his position due to wealth of material. Maryland,
the only college team that defeated Hopkins last year, loses the majority of its team while all other oponents lose as many veterans if not
more. If one adds to this fact that the coaching staff at Homewood
is as efficient if not more so than any other group in the country, we
can see no reason why this year's twelve should not be one of the most
powerful in the history of the institution.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 27, 1931

HULLABALOO WORK IS 15 Veteran Stickmen
Available This Year
PROCRESSING SWIFTLY
Photographer On Campus For
Last Time To Take Photographs For Year Book
With the photographer on campus, work on the Hullabaloo is progressing swiftly. Throughout this
week, the sundry group, activity
and fraternity photographs have
been taken. As this is the last time
the photographer will be on campus, it is advised that all seniors
who have not yet done so have their
individual, photographs taken. Appointments may be mad through
P. 0. box 655 or at the Hullabaloo
office in Levering Hall every day.
Sponsors Are Chosen

Sponsors for the eight eminent
social activities of the collegiate
year have all been selected and their
individual portraits are being taken
during the photographer's visit, according to a report emanating from
the Hullabaloo office. The eight
promenades which have the distinction of a sponsor are: First Cotillion, Barnstormers, Second Cotillion, Musical Club. Interfraternity
Ball, Final Cotillion, Night Club
Party and Senior Ball. The last
last three functions are part of the
June Week program.

Only 14 of a class of 325 freshmen in the undergraduate departments of the Johns Hopkins University were forced to discontinue
their studies at Homewood because
of the official regulation requiring
the dropping of students who have
failed in more than three courses.
"That's an unusually small percentage," declared Dr. E. W. Berry,
dean, yesterday. "I'm very much
Pleased with this year's freshman
class."
Twelve
sophomores
were
dropped, it was also announced.
Four undergraduates who were second-year men, but who were given
only first-year rating because of insufficient credits, also failed out. No
juniors or seniors were dropped.
"This is partly due to strictness
in entrance regulations and to postponed fraternity rushing," said the
Hopkins dean.

"An Engineer's 'Hobby'" was
the subject of an address delivered
before the Engineers' Club at 6
West Fayette Street by Mr. Malcolm W. Hill, Hopkins alumnus,
Wednesday afternoon. The speaker,
an active consulting engineer, has
been a member of this Club for
more than twenty-five years. His
talk about an engineer's "hobby"
and his viewpoint on Oriental Rugs
as an investment in pleasure and
profit was appreciatively received
by the audience.

Tomorrow evening the Black and
Blue basketball team will close this
season's campaign with the St.
St. Johns' tussle at Annapolis. In
their last encounter, both teams displayed a brand of ball that has always been present in Jay-Johnnie
battles. The game was chock full
of speed with neither team displaying any outstanding advantage
over the other.
Jays Not Conceded Chance to Win

Although the Jays were victorious 25-24, they are conceded little
chance of repeating because of recent defeats administered by other
rivals. Last week Loyola romped
off with a 43-25 victory; and
Maryland, this past \Vednesday,
trounced the Jays for the second
time this season, 31-22.
The Terrapins simply could not
be stopped. They grabbed the lead
in the early part of the tussle and
retained it throughout. Ronkin,
Chalmers and Berger gave another
brilliant exhibition of team play

Jack Taylor Shows Up Well

For the Jays, Jack Taylor shoed
up best. He fought hard and with
a little more assistance from his
teammates, would have played a
much better game. Both Kelly
brothers seemed off form while Silverman had the misfortune of being removed by the pers9nal foul
route.
From the opening minutes of
play it was apparent that Maryland
would have little difficulty in defeating Hopkins. Ronkin began to
display speed that dazzled the Jays.
He repeatedly looped shots from
all angles under the basket. Consequently, at the end of the half,
the Old Liners were leading 20-11.
Md. Clik at High Speed

The early minutes of the second
half found Maryland still clicking
at high speed. With but eight minutes to play they had piled up an
overwhelming 31-14 lead. At this
point Coach Shipley, of Maryland,
removed the whole varsity team.
The final score—Maryland, 31;
Hopkins, 22.
This is the third year in succession that the Terrapins have conquered the Jays.
'Disastrous Season' for Jays

From the standpoint of victories,
the Black and Blue basketball team
has had a most disastrous season.
Thus far they have won but four
games out of fifteen. Besides losing both jousts to Maryland, they
also were conquered twice by another rival, Loyola. However, one
could hardly have expected any
better. With no regulars from last
year's team to start with, Coach
Darley was confronted with the
task of constructing an entirely
new team.
Fortunately several of the new
players had had high school experience, but good team work can not
